creditline: Gift of the Clark Center for Japanese Art & Culture; formerly given to the Center by Mr and Mrs Makiji Hase
description: fan with minimal landscape scene; three horizontal banks with trees; three faint, small boats URQ; wispy calligraphy L half; signature LRC, stamps center R and LRC
inscription: L half of fan: あかしがたこよひの月乃影きよく波ぢはるけきふねぞこぎ行く (On Akashi Bay / this evening\'s moon / is glittering brightly -- / boats far out at sea / are rowing away.) (SA)
markings: R center, red oval relief seal; LRC, two red square seals; sticker R roller cap: [Gyokuran]
medium: Folding fan, mounted as hanging scroll; ink on paper sized with mica
text: Teahouses and traditional Japanese houses have built-in recessed display spaces, called tokonoma. The tokonoma is usually decorated with a hanging scroll, flower arrangement, and small objects. For a tea ceremony, the host would meditate on the participants and occasion to create a special collection of objects to commemorate the event. In this particular display, both objects allude to moonlight: the fan features a poem about “the evening moon,” and the tea caddy is made from the “night-glow shell” (green turban) sea snail.
title: Akashi Bay
